Fakta: FLUOR I SKISM√òRING:
Milj√∏farlig fluor brukes hovedsakelig i pulver som smeltes og legges p√• til slutt i sm√∏reprosessen.
Disse pulvertypene har vist seg og ha helt unike vannavst√∏tende egenskaper som gir ekstremt god glid. De er vanskelig √• erstatte med mer milj√∏vennlige produkter.

I over to √•r har Gr√∏nnestad jobbet med doktorgradsstudien. I 2015 fant man tilsvarende funn i meitemark i Holmenkollen. Det gjorde at forskeren ville unders√∏ke om det ogs√• var tilfellet i Gran√•sen.

Johannes H√∏sflot Kl√¶bo mener det ikke b√∏r v√¶re n√∏dvendig √• bruke skism√∏ring med fluor i langrennssporten.üì∑ Geir Olsen / NTB scanpix

LES MER: Fluortestingen skapte sterke reaksjoner. N√• kan den bli droppet.

I Trondheim er man ogs√• bekymret over det som kommer frem. Utbyggingsleder i Gran√•sen, Mona √Ösg√•rd, reagerer etter √• ha blitt kjent med studien.

"Scary" findings in animals in Norwegian World Cup races: - Can stay there for a hundred years
In 2025, the ski world championship is most likely to be held in Gran√•sen in Trondheim. In these trails a discovery has been made that causes concern.
06 Nov 2019, 15:24 by Viljam Brodahl
It is Dagbladet who on Wednesday published an article on the findings of a new doctoral study.
Researcher Randi Gr√∏nnestad is at the forefront of the work where large levels of PFAS (perfluorinated substances) have been found in soil, meadows and mice in the ski area around Gran√•sen in Trondheim. The levels are compared to a reference area without skiing activity.
In conclusion, fluoride from ski lubrication is not just a problem in winter. The substances remain in nature and the environment throughout the year.
- It's scary that we find it in the animals in the summer, long after the snow has melted, says Gr√∏nnestad.


READ THIS? Contested and environmentally hazardous ski lubrication is prohibited to produce in 2020: - We will use it if competitors use it




Gran√•sen not only attracts skiers. Animals are also part of the trails. l√∏ Vegard Eggen


Facts: FLUOR IN SKI LUBRICATION:
Environmentally hazardous fluorine is mainly used in powders which are melted and finally applied in the lubrication process.
These powder types have been found to have unique water-repellent properties that provide extremely good slip. They are difficult to replace with more environmentally friendly products.
All ski lubrication manufacturers are constantly working to find environmentally friendly solutions that produce as good results as the powder types that are banned from producing after 2020.



Randi Gr√∏nnestad is a researcher at NTNU.üì∑ NTNU

Can stay for 100 years
For over two years, Gr√∏nnestad has been working on the doctoral study. In 2015, similar discoveries were found in the country of Holmenkollen. This meant that the researcher wanted to investigate whether this was also the case in Gran√•sen.
In 2025, the ski world championship will be arranged at this location after all the sun marks. Trondheim is the only applicant for the championship.
- If you have found similar in Holmenkollen, it is not a surprise that it exists in Gran√•sen as well. There are areas where there is a lot of skiing, says Guri Hetland, project manager for the Ski World Championships in Trondheim in 2025.
What worries Gr√∏nnestad the most is the high level of substances. The fluorine composition found in the Gran√•sen area is similar to that found in ski lubrication.
- It is clear that ski lubrication is the background for these substances in this area. Substances are very slowly degraded in nature. It will remain for decades, perhaps up to a hundred years, after it is released. It's problematic, says Gr√∏nnestad.
She adds that the discovery is made among animals at the bottom of the food chain. Other studies show that fluoride substances can accumulate up the food chain. That way, it can eventually end up in animal humans eating.
It is known that fluorine substances found in ski lubrication can adversely affect the hormone system, the immune system and can be carcinogenic to humans.
Nevertheless, Gr√∏nnestad is aware that the amount of the substance found in Gran√•sen is not at the level that has shown great risk to human health.

Guri Hetland is project manager for the Ski World Championships in Gran√•sen in 2025. Here during Trondheim Ski Show last year.üì∑ JON OLAV NESVOLD / BILDBYR√ÖN NORWAY

Kl√¶bo thinks it must be taken
Johannes H√∏sflot Kl√¶bo responds to the discovery of the environmental toxins in Gran√•sen.
- In the big picture, there is no doubt that we are engaged in entertainment. It is not good for the environment at all that we should use products that damage the environment to go a tenth or one or two seconds faster, says the ski star to Adresseavisen, adding:
- This is our job and we live off the snow. It is important that measures are taken, and it is important for us that there is a regulation that can limit this and apply to everyone. We should not use harmful health products to speed up the tenths. We are entertainment, not anything else, he says.
The 23-year-old has the support of his closest sparring partner. Grandfather K√•re H√∏sflot, on the other hand, is not surprised by the discovery.
"No, I am not," says the grandfather.


Johannes H√∏sflot Kl√¶bo believes it should not be necessary to use ski lubrication with fluorine in cross-country sports.üì∑ Geir Olsen / NTB scanpix

Mentioned abroad
The study is now attracting international attention. On Wednesday, the findings were published in the renowned US journal Environmental Science & Technology.
- It is clear that they think these are interesting findings, says Gr√∏nnestad.
The Environment Agency is concerned about such discoveries of environmental toxins. Still, one looks positively at the study. It helps the Directorate in the work to stop the discharge of the hazardous pollutants.
- All research that highlights this better we take with us in our work to regulate more perfluorinated substances, says Heidi Morka, section director of the Environment Directorate.

In 2025, the ski world championships are to be arranged in Gran√•sen.üì∑ Vegard Eggen

Gran√•sen leader: - Very unlucky
Trondheim is also concerned about what's coming. Development leader in Gran√•sen, Mona √Ösg√•rd, responds after becoming familiar with the study.
- I find it very unfortunate the discovery made in our area. We welcome the ban coming next year, she says.
She is aiming for the EU connection to be introduced in 2020. From next year, it will be prohibited to produce environmentally hazardous fluorine lubrication, but not to use it.
The Cross-Country Committee of the Norwegian Ski Federation has also decided that there should be a fluorine ban in the classes up to and including 16 years.

Facts: WHAT IS PROHIBITED?
On 1 June 2020, the EU introduces a directive that prohibits the production and marketing of products containing an environmentally harmful fluorine compound that is also used in ski lubrication.
The hazardous substances that are now banned (per- and polyfluorinated alkyl substances - PFAS) have unique water and fat-repellent properties.
They are used today, among other things, as slipcovers in cookware, ski lubrication and in casual clothes.
PFASs are highly degradable, and some types of fluorine compounds have been detected at relatively high levels in environmental samples.
The drug can cause birth defects and cancer, and it is suspected that such substances may affect the immune system and cause metabolic disorders.
The ban has no connection with the Norwegian Ski Federation's ban on fluorine in age-based cross-country skiing already this season. The fluoride products are expensive and the federation's ban is a desire to keep costs down for young athletes.

Source: Environment Directorate


- We can do nothing but encourage people not to use ski lubrication with fluoride for environmental reasons, says √Ösg√•rd.
In Oslo, people are also encouraged to think about the use of fluorine lubrication.
- It would not have surprised me if you found the same findings here. The curse of the carbon is the time of decomposition. A ban now will not correct what is already there. It is a bit worrying, says Ole Kristian S√∏rland, leader of the Holmenkollen ski slopes.
